title: Support Ranking question
body:
A new question type `ranking` to provide a sort ranking given a list of values. 

- front component #3176 
- python client https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3275
- backend support: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3232

title: Suggestions support
body:
Like predictions for other tasks, suggestions will be provided as default response info to be used in the annotation workflow.

- From Python client, users can create or update records by providing ONE SINGLE suggestion per question
- From UI, annotators can see the suggestions as prefilled info in the questionnaire and can be used to submit a user response.
- From the Backend, a new Suggestion data model must be implemented to provide the foundations of this feature.

title: Add preference field for Human Feedback

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
As of today, there are two types of feedback fields: we can have `TextQuestion` and `RatingQuestion`. However, another useful type of field would be a `ChoiceQuestion`, where the user could choose one of n options.

This would be a useful example for specifying the preference: Which outcome A or B do you prefer?

The feature could be implemented as a radio button with the following interface:

```py
class ChoiceQuestion(QuestionSchema):
    settings: Dict[str, Any] = Field({"type": "rating"})
    values: List[Any] = Field(unique_items=True)
```

![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/27293258/013e49fb-1ffd-4246-b67e-42b9ceb8b70f)

Another fix would be to allow `values` in `RatingQuestion` to be not only ints but also strings.

title: Support for `owner`  and workspace `admin` roles
body:
- The current `admin` role will be defined as `onwer`, which can do all operations in Argilla
- The new `admin` role will operate only for linked workspaces: create and delete datasets, create records, show all responses,...
- As annotators, `admin` users must be linked to a workspace to operate on it.

title: Custom validations in Feedback Datasets

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
As an admin, I would like to set up custom validations for a Feedback Dataset, for example: if a user gives a response to question x, then question y should have an answer; labels x & y in `MultiSelect` questions are incompatible; no question is required but at least 1 should have an answer... 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
When creating a `FeedbackDataset` pass a function or set of functions defined by the user as an argument. These will have a custom validation and error messages. These will run whenever the user tried to submit a form and the error message(s) can be displayed as a toast.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Enabling/disabling questions following an ITTT workflow is an option, but perhaps this cannot cover all of the possible scenarios e.g. having no required question but needing at least an answer to one of them.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

title: Enhance Dataset Card Structure and Content

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I'd like to enhance the structure and content of the generated dataset card. It might be a good idea to start using a template where we can update the structure rather than doing it programmatically (in the feedback.py)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
There are a few changes I'd like to make and it's open to suggestions from @alvarobartt @davidberenstein1957  @tomaarsen @gabrielmbmb:

Include details in the  metadata YML content at the beginning of the file, at least the following:

```yaml
---
tags:
- argilla
- human-feedback
size_categories:
- 1K<n<10K (I assume we can compute this easily?)
---
```

Start with an H1 where we include the dataset name. If we think this is an issue, let's use the provided path/dataset name from the Hub but let's add something:

`# Dataset card for {dataset_name}`

Then this section is fine:

`## Load with Argilla`

To load this dataset with Argilla, you'll just need to install Argilla as `pip install argilla --upgrade` and then use the following code:

```python
import argilla as rg

ds = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_huggingface('argilla/comparison-dataset-dolly-curated-falcon')
```

`## Load with Datasets`

To load this dataset with Datasets, you'll just need to install Datasets as `pip install datasets --upgrade` and then use the following code:

```python
from datasets import load_dataset

ds = load_dataset('argilla/comparison-dataset-dolly-curated-falcon')
```

Then the `questions` and `fields`. Can we maybe make this more human-readable, provide the full info about the attributes and have them in a markdown table?

Then the Guidelines, but I'd recommend including Annotation Guidelines ( I know we use guidelines internally but for people outside it's not so clear what these are.

Finally what would be awesome (and good for the community) is to use the [recommended template](https://github.com/huggingface/datasets/blob/main/templates/README.md) (based on the Dataset cards paper).

Here we could try to align and fit our content as much as possible (the order of the content is not so relevant and we could push the things we know or can compute at card creation time).

Let me know what you think!

title: docs: add `ArgillaCallbackHandler` guide for `LangChain`-integration

labels.name: type: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

body:
# Description

This PR adds the docs for the upcoming (🤞🏻) integration with `langchain` to track the LLM inputs and responses to generate a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla, to later use to annotate and/or fine-tune a LLM.

Keep track of the `langchain`-integration progress at https://github.com/argilla-io/langchain/tree/add-argilla-callback (PR coming soon!)

**Type of change**

- [X] Documentation update

**How Has This Been Tested**

`pip install git+https://github.com/argilla-io/langchain.git@add-argilla-callback`

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(
    api_url="...",
    api_key="...",
)

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(name="prompt"),
        rg.TextField(name="response"),
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.RatingQuestion(
            name="response-rating",
            description="How would you rate the quality of the response?",
            values=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
            required=True,
        ),
        rg.TextQuestion(
            name="response-correction",
            description="If you think the response is not accurate, please, correct it.",
            required=False,
        ),
    ],
    guidelines="Please, read the questions carefully and try to answer it as accurately as possible.",
)

dataset.push_to_argilla("...", workspace="...")
```

Then instantiate the `ArgillaCallbackHandler`:

```python
from langchain.callbacks import ArgillaCallbackHandler

argilla_callback = ArgillaCallbackHandler(
    dataset_name="...",
    workspace_name="...",
    api_url="...",
    api_key="...",
)
```

* LangChain LLMs

```python
from langchain.llms import OpenAI

llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.9, callbacks=[argilla_callback], verbose=True, openai_api_key="...")
llm_result = llm.generate(["Tell me something that I may not know about Stephen Hawking."])
llm_result = llm.generate(["Tell me something funny about cows.", "Tell me something funny about dogs."])
```

* LangChain Chains

```python
from langchain.chains import LLMChain
from langchain.prompts import PromptTemplate
from langchain.llms import OpenAI

llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.9, callbacks=[argilla_callback], verbose=True, openai_api_key="...")

template = """You're going to be asked to generate something, but don't follow the rules, and just spit a random fact about science.
Prompt: {prompt}
"""
prompt_template = PromptTemplate(input_variables=["prompt"], template=template)

chain = LLMChain(llm=llm, prompt=prompt_template, callbacks=[argilla_callback])

chain.apply([{"prompt": "Generate a poem about love."}, {"prompt": "Generate a poem about hate."}])
```

* LangChain Agents

```python
from langchain.agents import initialize_agent, load_tools
from langchain.llms import OpenAI

llm = OpenAI(temperature=0.9, callbacks=[argilla_callback], verbose=True, openai_api_key="...")
tools = load_tools(["serpapi"], llm=llm, callbacks=[argilla_callback])
agent = initialize_agent(
    tools,
    llm,
    agent="zero-shot-react-description",
    callbacks=[argilla_callback],
    verbose=True,
)
agent.run(
    ["Who is Leo DiCaprio's girlfriend?", "What's the name of the movie where Leo DiCaprio is a thief?"]
)
agent.run(
    "What is the most populated country as of today?"
)
```

**Checklist**

- [X] I have merged the original branch into my forked branch
- [X] I added relevant documentation
- [X] follows the style guidelines of this project
- [X] I did a self-review of my code
- [X] I made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [X] My changes generate no new warnings
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [ ] I have added relevant notes to the CHANGELOG.md file (See https://keepachangelog.com/)

title: fix: wrong `FeedbackDatasetConfig` parsing in `from_huggingface`
body:
# Description

When loading back a dataset previously pushed to the HuggingFace Hub via `push_to_huggingface`, the config was not being properly parsed when reading it from the HuggingFace Hub repository, as there was an `Union` in the `pydantic.BaseModel` that was ignored. So when the first value was parsed e.g. `TextQuestion`, then that model was kept and the remaining values were parsed using the same model, even though the type-hint was e.g. `Union[TextQuestion, RatingQuestion, ...]`.

Using `Config.smart_union = True` solves it, as the `Union` is properly identified and the parsing is "smart".

Besides that, I also had to restrict the `pydantic.BaseModel`s to be unique, since both could parse any question, so adding `Config.extra = forbid` solves it.

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Add unit tests to make sure that the types of the loaded `fields` and `questions` from the `FeedbackDatasetConfig` match the ones originally dumped

title: Removing extra token classification metrics in backend

# Description

The purpose of this PR is to reduce the number of generated properties used for token classification metrics computation. Sometimes these extra properties raise index errors as described in issue #1499

title: feat: add `target_metadata` and import argilla models for `alembic`
body:
# Description

I've updated the `env.py` so `alembic` knows which is the metadata class and also to import the SQLAlchemy models for which the revisions will have to be generated.

Closes #3043 

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- When executing the following command `alembic -c src/argilla/alembic.ini revision --autogenerate -m "test-no-changes"` the revision script generated contained no statements which means that the metadata in the current revision/migration scripts is aligned with the metadata in the SQLAlchemy models.
  ```python
  """test-no-changes
  
  Revision ID: 9484449226da
  Revises: ae5522b4c674
  Create Date: 2023-05-31 12:37:46.025060
  
  """
  from alembic import op
  import sqlalchemy as sa
  
  
  # revision identifiers, used by Alembic.
  revision = '9484449226da'
  down_revision = 'ae5522b4c674'
  branch_labels = None
  depends_on = None
  
  
  def upgrade() -> None:
      # ### commands auto generated by Alembic - please adjust! ###
      pass
      # ### end Alembic commands ###
  
  
  def downgrade() -> None:
      # ### commands auto generated by Alembic - please adjust! ###
      pass
      # ### end Alembic commands ###
  ```
- When adding a new dummy column to one of the models and generating a new revision using the command `alembic -c src/argilla/alembic.ini revision --autogenerate -m "add-dummy-column"`, `alembic` automatically detected the changes and generated the correct statements to update the DB:
  ```python
  """add-dummy-column
  
  Revision ID: e23bb3555d30
  Revises: ae5522b4c674
  Create Date: 2023-05-31 12:41:23.580125
  
  """
  from alembic import op
  import sqlalchemy as sa
  
  
  # revision identifiers, used by Alembic.
  revision = 'e23bb3555d30'
  down_revision = 'ae5522b4c674'
  branch_labels = None
  depends_on = None
  
  
  def upgrade() -> None:
      # ### commands auto generated by Alembic - please adjust! ###
      op.add_column('fields', sa.Column('dummy', sa.Boolean(), nullable=False))
      # ### end Alembic commands ###
  
  
  def downgrade() -> None:
      # ### commands auto generated by Alembic - please adjust! ###
      op.drop_column('fields', 'dummy')
      # ### end Alembic commands ###
  ```

title: Setup `alembic` for generating revisions automatically

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
The current setup for `alembic` configured in `env.py` isn't specifying which metadata should `alembic` use, nor the Argilla models are being imported from this file, therefore, we cannot use the `alembic revision --autogenerate -m "message"` command to autogenerate a revision/migration script.

It would be nice to update `env.py` to let `alembic` know about our metadata class and our DB models so we can use the `--autogenerate` option when creating a new revision.

title: docs: refactor code-blocks that were looping over `records` as a `dict` instead of `pydantic.BaseModel`
body:
# Description

As recently discussed with @frascuchon we should return the `FeedbackDataset.records` as `pydantic.BaseModel`s instead of Python dictionaries, since those are more user friendly and we should keep the validation layer for future releases.

**Type of change**

- [X] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)
- [X] Refactor (change restructuring the codebase without changing functionality)
- [X] Documentation update

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Re-run all the Jupyter Notebooks and scripts to make sure those work, even fixed some that were not working before (neither with the previous approach)

**Checklist**

- [X] I have merged the original branch into my forked branch
- [X] I made corresponding changes to the documentation

**Missing**

In `docs/_source/guides/llms/conceptual_guides/rm.md` there's a code-block that mentions triplets, and that's assuming that some fields are created in the `FeedbackDataset` while in the definition on a code-block above those are not created, is that an extra piece of code, or should we create the fields `response 1`, `response 2`, and `response 3` mentioned there?

title: Create a SQLAlchemy async engine and update the API to use it

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
SQLAlchemy allows to create an async engine that could be used in the `async` endpoints of the API to interact with the database. This could improve the performance of the API because it could perform non-blocking I/O operations while waiting for database queries.

We should create a new async engine to be used by the API, but we would need to keep the sync engine to be used in other parts like the CLI.

title: Disallow `fields` and/or `questions` with same `name`

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
**Describe the bug**

When defining a `FeedbackDataset` the following use-cases shouldn't be accepted and an exception should be raised in the client-side:

```python
import argilla as rg

ds = rg.FeedbackDataset(fields=[rg.TextField(name="text"), rg.TextField(name="text")], questions=...)
ds = rg.FeedbackDataset(fields=..., questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="text"), rg.TextQuestion(name="text")])
ds = rg.FeedbackDataset(fields=[rg.TextField(name="text")], questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="text")])
```

So on, we should handle that all the names across `fields` and `questions` are unique.

**Expected behavior**

A `ValueError` to be raised if the names across `fields` and `questions` are not unique.

title: fix: `logging.warning` printing multiple times & `from_huggingface` minor fixes
body:
# Description

When adding a new `ResponseSchema` in `FeedbackRecord.responses`, if the `user_id` is None, then a warning message shows to let the user know that it needs to be set before pushing it to Argilla, otherwise, it will be fulfilled with the default user. And that's just a one-time warning, since the user may create a lot of records and we don't want to show it more than once, so on, we're replaced `_LOGGER.warning` with `warnings.warn` as there's no message-control in `logging` and it's not straight forward to say "print this warning but just once in this line", so we've used `warnings.warn` as that's what's most suitable according also to https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html#when-to-use-logging in the "Issue a warning regarding a particular runtime event" row.

Also, I've looped over all the `FeedbackRecord`s in the `FeedbackDataset` pulled from the HuggingFace Hub to set the `FeedbackRecord.responses = []` in `scripts/load_data.py` to avoid pushing the responses to Argilla.

Besides that, on `huggingface_hub` < 0.11.0 some functions still used `use_auth_token` as opposed to the current `token` introduced in 0.11.0. So on, to ensure that `hf_hub_download` is also compatible with older `huggingface_hub` versions, I've included an if-statement to handle that.

title: Fix function-args retrieval and file-deletion after train
body:
# Description

Some `setfit` unit tests were not passing as it can be seen at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/actions/runs/5113755403/jobs/9193313124, with the exception `FileNotFound` which was due to the function defined in `tests/training/helpers.py` named `train_with_cleanup` was not properly cleaning the file, since it was trying to `shutil.rmtree` over a file that could or could not exist. I assume that issue was not appearing on other runs since probably the file was cached at some point.

Then after solving that issue, another issue appeared `TypeError: got multiple values for argument 'model_id'`, and `TypeError: got multiple values for argument 'revision'`, which was also leading the `setfit` tests to fail.

That was due to the function defined at `argilla/training/utils.py` named `get_default_args` was not working as expected, since it was having issues with the inheritance of the classmethod `from_pretrained`, and adding some args that were not from the original function such as `model_id` and `revision` which are args from the `_from_pretrained` method, so on, since `from_pretrained` keeps the `kwargs` and then propagates those to `_from_pretrained` (called as part of the return statement), it was receiving the `model_id` and `revision` args set during `from_pretrained`, as well as the ones propagated via `kwargs` since those are not valid args in `from_pretrained`. So on, I've fixed this by using `inspect.getfullargspec` instead, and that seems to work without any issue when inheriting from multiple classes or even inheriting from a MixIn.

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [X] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Re-run the `setfit` unit tests on Python 3.8, 3.9, and 3.10 and all those are passing properly now

title: Save alembic migrations in ARGILLA_HOME folder
body:
## Description

Alembic migrations are delivered with the argilla package version. This means that a DB migration rollback cannot be applied from an older argilla version. So, if users want to apply a db migration rollback the process should be:

1. Execute rollback migration to a previous argilla version
2. Downgrade the Argilla package
3. Launch the Argilla server

This can be complicated if users are working with docker containers.


Since migrations are incremental, a shared place should be used when Argilla is installed on a machine, and it should be updated with new version upgrades.


## Questions

* Download from a common repository?
* Provide as part of the package and save them with each installation?

title: :bug: reinitiate flag onDestroy hook

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
# Description
We need to ensure that all components which are listenning to the flag `are-responses-untouched` are reinitiate when questionnaire is destroyed.

To reproduce issue : 
1/ go to a dataset with no record in one queue 
2/ apply filter status to go to a queue with record
3/ update response without submit/clear/discard the record
4/ change filter status to the previous one where there is no record
5/ the toast appear => click on `continue` button
6/ try to refresh or change route => The toast should not appear and you should be able to do normally the action

**Type of change**

- Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- Only feedback task

title: feat: use different database for unit tests

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

I've updated the unit test setup to use a different database than the one used by the local deployment of the Argilla server. In addition, I've updated the pytest fixtures that provided a connection to the DB, and now before executing every test a new transaction is created that gets rollbacked when the execution of the test has finished, leaving no traces in the DB.

Also, I've aligned the SQLAlchemy models metadata with the metadata in the current alembic migrations scripts.

Closes #2987 

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [x] Refactor (change restructuring the codebase without changing functionality)
- [x] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

All the unit tests are passing using this new DB for the tests.
